headline.seo: Health Board Approves Bloomberg’s Soda Ban
headline.print_headline: Health Panel Approves Restriction on Sale of Large Sugary Drinks
headline.main: Health Panel Approves Restriction on Sale of Large Sugary Drinks

docs.abstract: New York City Board of Health approves a controversial ban on the sale of large sodas and other sugary drinks at restaurants, street carts and movie theaters; measure, seeking to reduce increasing obesity rates, is the first of its kind in the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: The measure, which bars the sale of sweetened drinks larger than 16 ounces, will take effect in six months unless blocked by a judge.
docs.snippet: The measure, which bars the sale of sweetened drinks larger than 16 ounces, will take effect in six months unless blocked by a judge.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a recent column by Roger Cohen on organic food.
docs.snippet: Readers respond to a recent column by Roger Cohen on organic food.

headline.seo: In Soda Ban, Soft-Drink Industry Braces for a Long Fight
headline.print_headline: In Soda Fight, Industry Focuses on the Long Run
headline.main: In Soda Fight, Industry Focuses on the Long Run

docs.abstract: Soft-drink industry plans to continue campaign against New York City's proposed ban on the sale of large-size sodas, which is expected to be approved by city's Board of Health; industry officials, fearful that stricter limits on sales could incite a national trend, and a long-term erosion of profits, say they will focus on the long run, and may even consider a legal challenge to the restriction.
docs.lead_paragraph: Soft-drink officials concede that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s ban on large sodas is expected to be approved by New York City’s Board of Health on Thursday — for now.
docs.snippet: Soft-drink officials concede that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s ban on large sodas is expected to be approved by New York City’s Board of Health on Thursday — for now.

headline.main: City's Health Boards Have Ruled on Livestock and Tattoos. Up Next: Soda.

docs.abstract: City Room blog on the history of New York City's health boards, which have safeguarded the city since 1805; current Board of Health has 11 members, all health professionals appointed by the mayor and approved by the City Council, who serve six-year terms and cannot be dismissed without cause; latest challenge before the board is proposed amendment to the health code that would ban the sale of large-size sugary drinks. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The 11 largely faceless members of the New York City Board of Health who will decide Thursday whether to ban the sale of super-size sugary soft drinks in certain establishments trace their authority to 1805, when the power to monitor the city's health was formally vested in a city "inspector," John Pintard, a Renaissance man who is most famous for popularizing Santa Claus . Meeting for the first time, a board of health ordered the evacuation of neighborhoods plagued by yellow fever and began collecting mortality statistics to "furnish data for reflection and calculation." (Sometimes, though, epidemics were declared only belatedly because they were bad for business.)

headline.print_headline: City’s Health Boards Have Ruled on Livestock and Tattoos. Up Next: Soda.
headline.main: With Rulings on Rubbish and Tattoos, Safeguarding the City for Centuries

docs.abstract: The Board of Health, an obscure city board that will rule on a proposed ban on large sugary drinks, has had a major influence on the health habits of New Yorkers.
docs.snippet: The Board of Health, an obscure city board that will rule on a proposed ban on large sugary drinks, has had a major influence on the health habits of New Yorkers.

headline.seo: ‘An Epidemic of Absence’ Review - Seeing Hygiene as Driver of Disease
headline.print_headline: A Messy, Exuberant Case Against Being Too Clean
headline.main: A Messy, Exuberant Case Against Being Too Clean

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book An Epidemic of Absence: A New Way of Understanding Allergies and Autoimmune Diseases by Moises Velasquez-Manoff.
docs.lead_paragraph: Has a loss of intestinal bacteria caused our immune systems to go haywire? Moises Velasquez-Manoff lays out the hygiene hypothesis.
docs.snippet: Has a loss of intestinal bacteria caused our immune systems to go haywire? Moises Velasquez-Manoff lays out the hygiene hypothesis.

headline.seo: Door to Door in Oklahoma City, Preaching Healthy Living
headline.print_headline: Door to Door in the Heartland, Preaching Healthy Living
headline.main: Door to Door in the Heartland, Preaching Healthy Living

docs.abstract: Local governments across the country are using money allocated by the Affordable Care Act to create programs that help curb the incidence of obesity and other diseases and promote healthy lifestyles; trend is part of a national effort set in motion by the law to move from a reactionary health care system to one based on prevention.
docs.lead_paragraph: With money allocated by the Obama health care law, local governments are creating programs to help curb the incidence of obesity and other diseases and promote healthy lifestyles.
docs.snippet: With money allocated by the Obama health care law, local governments are creating programs to help curb the incidence of obesity and other diseases and promote healthy lifestyles.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

headline.main: Vital Signs | Patterns: Metabolic Syndrome and the Teenage Brain

docs.abstract: Dr Antonio Convit study published online in journal Pediatrics suggests that metabolic syndrome, the combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes, is associated with brain changes and cognitive deficiencies not just in adults, but also in teenagers with the disorder. (M)y
docs.lead_paragraph: Metabolic syndrome, the combination of disorders that increases the risk of cardiovascular disease and diabetes , is known to be associated with brain changes and cognitive deficiencies in adults. Now a new study , published online in Pediatrics, has found a similar effect in teenagers with the disorder. Researchers compared 49 nondiabetic teenagers who had metabolic syndrome - high blood levels of glucose, low levels of high-density lipoprotein , high triglycerides , abdominal obesity and high blood pressure - with 64 young people who had fewer than three of those symptoms. Participants were given magnetic resonance brain scans and standard tests of memory, learning, attention and psychomotor ability.

headline.main: Is Organic Food Worth the Expense?

docs.abstract: A recent study questions the nutritional value of organic food, but are there other benefits? Is it smart to go organic in a time of global food shortages?
